item.title: Australia's thunderstorm asthma risk high - SBS News
item.description:
Australia's thunderstorm asthma risk high  SBS News

Australia is at risk of another potentially fatal thunderstorm asthma attack as the climate changes and allergens increase, a new study finds.

item.title: Silver linings can be found in those Thunderstorm Asthma clouds - Neos Kosmos
item.description:
Silver linings can be found in those Thunderstorm Asthma clouds  Neos Kosmos

On the two-year anniversary of the 2016 Thunderstorm Asthma event some thoughts and advice by someone who knows what life with asthma is about.

item.title: Thunderstorm asthma deaths: ambulance dispatch 'unlikely' factor – coroner - The Guardian
item.description:
Thunderstorm asthma deaths: ambulance dispatch 'unlikely' factor – coroner  The Guardian

Inquest into 10 Melbourne deaths had heard time from first wheezing to respiratory failure as little as 15 minutes.

item.title: Thunderstorm asthma inquest recommends triple-0 callers be given ambulance ETA - ABC News
item.description:
Thunderstorm asthma inquest recommends triple-0 callers be given ambulance ETA  ABC News

The inquest into 2016's deadly thunderstorm asthma event has recommended callers to triple-0 be given an estimated time of arrival for ambulances.

item.title: Thunderstorm asthma Melbourne 2016: Deaths findings to be handed down - NEWS.com.au
item.description:
Thunderstorm asthma Melbourne 2016: Deaths findings to be handed down  NEWS.com.au

AMBULANCE Victoria will pilot a program which tells patients the wait time of ambulances following the 2016 thunderstorm asthma disaster which claimed the ...

item.title: A Study On The Deadly Melbourne Thunderstorm Asthma Outbreak Offers Predictive Clues - Forbes Now
item.description:
A Study On The Deadly Melbourne Thunderstorm Asthma Outbreak Offers Predictive Clues  Forbes Now

I know, I know…..thunderstorm asthma is counterintuitive. Most people think that rainfall should wash away allergens that trigger asthmatic response. I thought this too until my colleagues and I started looking into thunderstorm asthma. Researchers in the United Kingdom and Australia, for example, have been studying thunderstorm asthma for decades but virtually no research had been focused on a U.S. city. My colleague Dr. Andrew Grundstein initiated a study in partnership with researchers at the University of Georgia and Emory University. That study, published in the journal Thorax, indeed...

item.title: Ninth thunderstorm asthma victim - The Australian
item.description:
Ninth thunderstorm asthma victim  The Australian

The Victorian Department of Health and Human Services released the information today and said no further patients remain in hospital as a result of the unprecedented thunderstorm asthma event. Following the incident the Victorian government announced a state-wide review of the emergency response led by the Inspector-General of Emergency Management. The review will examine consideration of public warnings and health advice, support provided to emergency and the role of Emergency Management Victoria. Submissions to the review close this Monday. A separate coronial investigation will examine a...

item.title: Risk assessment for thunderstorm asthma event in SA - The Advertiser
item.description:
Risk assessment for thunderstorm asthma event in SA  The Advertiser

The adverse event promoted the Victorian Health Department to issue public asthma warnings after Melbourne suffered the world’s worst-known thunderstorm-induced asthma epidemic on November 21. A statement provided to The Advertiser from SA Health said: “SA Health is investigating the risks of a similar event occurring in South Australia as part of its public health research and, if warranted, prepare specific advice accordingly”. While the Asthma Foundation SA would not comment on whether they support SA Health issuing a similar warning system in South Australia, the organisation’s health s...

item.title: $15.56m overhaul after deadly storm - The Advertiser
item.description:
$15.56m overhaul after deadly storm  The Advertiser

Today’s State Government announcement comes as it releases its final report into last year’s deadly thunderstorm asthma event, which killed nine people. The unusual weather event on November 21-22 saw hospitals and emergency services swamped with unprecedented demand for help to treat thousands of Melburnians in respiratory distress. The report by the Inspector-General for Emergency Management, Tony Pearce, found no evidence the scenario could have been predicted, or that the storm would result in such demand for health services. Minister for Health Jill Hennessy said the government had acc...

item.title: Asthma study reveals storm risk - The Australian
item.description:
Asthma study reveals storm risk  The Australian

A new study into the freak Melbourne thunderstorm, which killed nine people and hospitalised about 8500, suggests as many as two in five people may have been affected — most of them with no history of asthma. Victorian researchers are warning of a “hidden population” that could be susceptible to recurrences of the November 21 disaster, which struck when freak weather coincided with spring grassland pollination. Hot winds and a sudden downpour led to the mass release of tiny allergen particles, triggering sudden and severe asthma attacks. The researchers, from Victoria’s Eastern Health netwo...

item.title: Storm asthma system rolled out - The Australian
item.description:
Storm asthma system rolled out  The Australian

The new monitoring, prediction and alert system will allow authorities to warn people about the risk of thunderstorm asthma up to three days before an event. Epidemic thunderstorm asthma is triggered by high grass pollen levels and a certain type of thunderstorm. READ MORE: Could thunderstorm asthma happen again? Health Minister Jill Hennessy on Sunday said the new forecasting system will help authorities and the public to better predict and better respond to thunderstorm asthma. “The great challenge with thunderstorm asthma and epidemic thunderstorm asthma was its scale, its severity, and ...

item.title: Asthma families’ ambo plea - The Australian
item.description:
Asthma families’ ambo plea  The Australian

Lives could have been saved ­during a deadly thunderstorm asthma event in Melbourne if people had been given accurate ambulance arrival times, victims’ families say. Seven men and three women died during or soon after the storm hit Melbourne on November 21, 2016. A combination of high pollen levels, strong winds, hot temperatures, air moisture and a cold front triggered severe asthma attacks and an unprecedented surge in demand for ambulances. Relatives of electrical fitter Priyantha Peiris said better estimated ambulance arrival times could have saved lives. The 57-year-old man died at the...

item.title: Australia's Queensland Tackles Climate-Driven Disease, Deaths - VOA News
item.description:
Australia's Queensland Tackles Climate-Driven Disease, Deaths  VOA News

The Queensland state government in Australia is to fund a new program to help combat killer heatwaves and outbreaks of disease caused by climate change. Authorities are even discussing imposing tobacco-style taxes against carbon polluters. The initiative comes as the United Nation chief warned that if the world does not take serious action by 2020, it risks the fallout from “runaway climate change.” The plan to tackle climate-related disease and deaths from heatwaves is part of the Queensland government's efforts to cut the state’s carbon emissions to zero by 2050. The strategy urges bureau...

item.title: Thunderstorm asthma victims left waiting for ambulances which had not been despatched - ABC News
item.description:
Thunderstorm asthma victims left waiting for ambulances which had not been despatched  ABC News

By Karen Percy Demand for ambulances was so high during Melbourne's thunderstorm asthma event that some people were told an ambulance was on its way when, in fact, a despatch "had not occurred", a coroner has heard. Ten people died in the November 2016 event, which saw rye grass pollen swept across the city during a dramatic a cool change. The pollen burst into very fine particles, sparking asthma-like symptoms in thousands of people across the city. A hearing into the deaths was told the Emergency Services Telecommunications Authority (ETSA), which operates the 000 emergency call service, ...

item.title: Lifesaving pill for hay fever, asthma sufferers - The Advertiser
item.description:
Lifesaving pill for hay fever, asthma sufferers  The Advertiser

Melbourne scientists found it teaches the immune system to tolerate the allergen for up to a decade, if given daily for four months over three years. By coincidence, the Alfred Hospital trial occurred during the thunderstorm asthma event in Melbourne in November 2016, which claimed nine lives and forced thousands to seek emergency medical treatment. Among the patients on the trial who were taking the tablet, none developed the potentially life-threatening complications. THUNDERSTORM ASTHMA EARLY WARNING SYSTEM ROLLED OUT ASTHMA STORM: HOW TO PROTECT YOURSELF WHY DID THUNDERSTORM ASTHMA VICT...

item.title: A “thunderstorm asthma” epidemic may lead Australia to a cure for the disease - Quartz
item.description:
A “thunderstorm asthma” epidemic may lead Australia to a cure for the disease  Quartz

On a sweltering afternoon in November 2016, the Bureau of Meteorology in the Australian state of Victoria issued a severe thunderstorm warning for several regional areas around metropolitan Melbourne. It was a relatively routine announcement for the time of the year. Thunderstorms are a common springtime occurrence in and around Australia’s second-largest city, whose famously changeable weather is said by locals to produce four seasons in a single day. But as it turned out, the hours following the November 21 alert were anything but routine. During that Monday evening and the following Tues...

item.title: The New Daily launches specialist ‘Health’ newsletter - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
The New Daily launches specialist ‘Health’ newsletter  mUmBRELLA*

National news website The New Daily is launching a monthly newsletter for those interested in health, wellbeing and fitness. Edited by Mahsa Fratantoni, the first edition of ‘Health’ will be available to The New Daily subscribers from November 26. Fratantoni joins the company after more than three years of freelance work across publications including Fitness First Magazine and WYZA. The latest newsletter adds to the industry super funds-owned publisher’s various specialist publications, including housing guide ‘Your Property’ and travel newsletter ‘Away’. Fratantoni said the publication wil...
